title: Ilana Davidson
text:
Ilana Davidson is an American <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="soprano">soprano</a> who has had an active international singing career in operas and concerts. She has sung on several recordings, including as a soloist on a recording of <a href="William%20Bolcom">William Bolcom</a>'s "Songs of Innocence and of Experience" with <a href="Leonard%20Slatkin">Leonard Slatkin</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Michigan">University of Michigan</a> chorus and orchestra which won four Grammy Awards including <a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Classical%20Album">Best Classical Album</a> in 2006. She is the co-artistic director of the Chamber music series <a href="ClassicalCafe">ClassicalCafe</a>. Early life and education
Raised in the Philadelphia, Pennsylvania region, she graduated from <a href="Carnegie%20Mellon%20University">Carnegie Mellon University</a> with a Bachelor of Music degree in vocal performance. She then pursued graduate studies at the <a href="Curtis%20Institute%20of%20Music">Curtis Institute of Music</a> where she earned a M.M. in Opera Performance and Voice. She appeared in several opera productions at Curtis, portraying such roles as the young girl in <a href="Viktor%20Ullmann">Viktor Ullmann</a>'s "<a href="Der%20Kaiser%20von%20Atlantis">Der Kaiser von Atlantis</a>", Despina in <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart</a>'s "<a href="Cos%C3%AC%20fan%20tutte">Così fan tutte</a>", Lady with a Hand Mirror in <a href="Dominick%20Argento">Dominick Argento</a>'s "<a href="Postcard%20from%20Morocco">Postcard from Morocco</a>", and Atalanta in <a href="George%20Frideric%20Handel">George Frideric Handel</a>'s "<a href="Serse">Serse</a>".
Davidson was a vocal fellow at the <a href="Tanglewood%20Music%20Center">Tanglewood Music Center</a> where she was a pupil of <a href="Phyllis%20Curtin">Phyllis Curtin</a>. She was the recipient of a <a href="Sullivan%20Foundation">William Matheus Sullivan Music Foundation Grant</a>. She is also a participant in the <a href="Aston%20Magna%20Early%20Music%20Academy">Aston Magna Early Music Academy</a>.
Career.
She sang Papagena for her European debut at the <a href="Staatsoper%20Stuttgart">Staatsoper Stuttgart</a>.
Davidson made her debut at <a href="Carnegie%20Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> as a soloist in William Bolcom's "Songs of Innocence and of Experience" under the baton of the composer with the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Symphony">St. Louis Symphony</a>. She made her debut at the Jugendstiltheater in Vienna as Die Königen in Krenek's "<a href="Das%20Geheime%20K%C3%B6nigreich">Das Geheime Königreich</a>". She sang the role of Gepopo in Ligeti's "Mysteries of the Macabre" in Amsterdam and also in concert with conductor Jonathan Sheffer and his Eos Orchestra at the <a href="New%20York%20Society%20for%20Ethical%20Culture">New York Society for Ethical Culture</a>. She performed the role of Amor in the first modern revival of <a href="Giovanni%20Legrenzi">Giovanni Legrenzi</a>'s "<a href="La%20divisione%20del%20mondo">La divisione del mondo</a>" at the <a href="Schwetzingen%20Festival">Schwetzingen Festival</a>.
Davidson was the soprano soloist in <a href="Johann%20Sebastian%20Bach">Johann Sebastian Bach</a>'s "<a href="Es%20erhub%20sich%20ein%20Streit%2C%20BWV%2019">Es erhub sich ein Streit, BWV 19</a>" with the <a href="Orchestra%20of%20Saint%20Luke%27s">Orchestra of Saint Luke's</a> and the <a href="New%20York%20Baroque%20Soloists">New York Baroque Soloists</a> under conductor <a href="Mary%20Greer">Mary Greer</a>. She later performed with both groups again as the soprano soloist in Handel's "<a href="Messiah%20%28Handel%29">Messiah</a>" and Bach's "<a href="Christmas%20Oratorio">Christmas Oratorio</a>."
Davidson was a soloist in William Bolcom's "Songs of Innocence and of Experience" under the baton of the composer with the <a href="University%20of%20Michigan">University of Michigan</a> orchestra and chorus; a performance that was recorded by <a href="Naxos%20Records">Naxos Records</a>. She performed in the world premiere of <a href="Libby%20Larson">Libby Larson</a>’s "Everyman Jack" at the <a href="Sonoma%20Opera">Sonoma Opera</a>. She portrayed The Wife in the New York premiere of <a href="Philip%20Glass">Philip Glass</a> and <a href="Robert%20Moran">Robert Moran</a>'s "<a href="The%20Juniper%20Tree%20%28opera%29">The Juniper Tree</a>" at <a href="Avery%20Fisher%20Hall">Avery Fisher Hall</a>".
Davidson performed in a concert of <a href="Ernst%20Krenek">Ernst Krenek</a>’s compositions at the <a href="Austrian%20Cultural%20Forum">Austrian Cultural Forum</a> in New York City. In 2015 she performed the world premiere of <a href="Juantio%20Becenti">Juantio Becenti</a>'s "The Obsidian Morning" at the <a href="New%20York%20Festival%20of%20Song">New York Festival of Song</a>. She also appeared at the <a href="Bard%20Music%20Festival">Bard Music Festival</a> with the <a href="American%20Symphony%20Orchestra">American Symphony Orchestra</a> as Mona Ginevra in <a href="Max%20von%20Schillings">Max von Schillings</a>’s opera "<a href="Mona%20Lisa%20%28opera%29">Mona Lisa</a>".
Davidson has made several appearances with the <a href="Dutch%20National%20Opera">Dutch National Opera</a> during her career, including Amor in Gluck's "<a href="Orfeo%20ed%20Euridice">Orfeo ed Euridice</a>", Chef der Gepopo in Ligeti's "<a href="Le%20Grand%20Macabre">Le Grand Macabre</a>", the first Flowermaiden in "<a href="Parsifal">Parsifal</a>", Oscar in "<a href="Un%20ballo%20in%20maschera">Un ballo in maschera</a>", and Susanna in "<a href="Le%20Nozze%20di%20Figaro">Le Nozze di Figaro</a>". She has also made appearances at the <a href="Florida%20Grand%20Opera">Florida Grand Opera</a> (Flora in "<a href="The%20Turn%20of%20the%20Screw">The Turn of the Screw</a>" and Amore in "<a href="L%27incoronazione%20di%20Poppea">L'incoronazione di Poppea</a>") and the <a href="Glimmerglass%20Opera">Glimmerglass Opera</a>.
